elements.content: Oligodiacetylenes (ODAs) with alternating ene–yne conjugated structure are significant materials for optical and electronic properties. Due to the low solubility of ODAs in common solvents, the synthetic approaches are limited. Here we disclose a new synthetic approach of ODAs without a side alkyl chain using a porous coordination polymer (PCP) as a sacrificial template. 1,2-Bis­(4-pyridyl)­butadiyne, which works as a monomer, was embedded in the flexible framework of the PCP, and ODAs were synthesized via utilization of the anisotropic thermal expansion of the PCP crystal. The oligomeric state of ODAs depends on the metal ion and coligand of the precursor.
elements.clean_text: Oligodiacetylenes (ODAs) with alternating ene-yne conjugated structure are significant materials for optical and electronic properties. Due to the low solubility of ODAs in common solvents, the synthetic approaches are limited. Here we disclose a new synthetic approach of ODAs without a side alkyl chain using a porous coordination polymer (PCP) as a sacrificial template. 1,2-Bis(4-pyridyl)butadiyne, which works as a monomer, was embedded in the flexible framework of the PCP, and ODAs were synthesized via utilization of the anisotropic thermal expansion of the PCP crystal. The oligomeric state of ODAs depends on the metal ion and coligand of the precursor.

elements.content: Since Wegner discovered the 1,4-diacetylene polymerization in solid state via a topochemical reaction, polydiacetylenes have been studied extensively owing to the unique alternating ene–yne conjugated structure. In this research field, control of the molecular structure is important for the design of optical and electronic properties. Oligodiacetylenes (ODAs) with the well-defined conjugated structure have also been the significant synthesis target. Engineered crystalline hosts with hydrogen or halogen bonding are useful for polydiacetylene synthesis, whereas ODAs with low polymerization degree are typically synthesized by using Sonogashira–Glaser coupling reactions or comicellar strategy. One of the issues with the sequential synthetic approaches is the difficulty to synthesize the structures without an alkyl side chain due to the low solubility in organic solvents. The alkyl chain sacrifices good conductive properties derived from the conjugated structure. Therefore, new routes are demanded for the synthesis of ODAs without an alkyl side chain.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Since Wegner discovered the 1,4-diacetylene polymerization in solid state via a topochemical reaction, polydiacetylenes have been studied extensively owing to the unique alternating ene-yne conjugated structure. In this research field, control of the molecular structure is important for the design of optical and electronic properties. Oligodiacetylenes (ODAs) with the well-defined conjugated structure have also been the significant synthesis target. Engineered crystalline hosts with hydrogen or halogen bonding are useful for polydiacetylene synthesis, whereas ODAs with low polymerization degree are typically synthesized by using Sonogashira-Glaser coupling reactions or comicellar strategy. One of the issues with the sequential synthetic approaches is the difficulty to synthesize the structures without an alkyl side chain due to the low solubility in organic solvents. The alkyl chain sacrifices good conductive properties derived from the conjugated structure. Therefore, new routes are demanded for the synthesis of ODAs without an alkyl side chain.

elements.content: In recent years, remarkable numbers of functional solids such as porous carbon, metal nanoparticles, and organic polymers are reported by use of porous coordination polymers (PCPs) or metal organic frameworks (MOFs) as sacrificial precursors. They are also a useful platform for the molecular synthesis. Sequential dimerization via the [2+2] cycloaddition, [2+2+2] cyclotrimerization, and the formation of an anhydride bridge between free carboxylic groups are examples. These topochemical reactions were conducted by use of the robust crystal structure of PCP/MOFs, and this is not applicable for the various oligomer formations. This is because of the difficulty for the preparation of such topotactic reaction environments for oligomers. Development of the synthetic route of organic oligomers such as ODA without a side alkyl chain by use of PCP/MOFs is therefore of general importance and a challenge. For the synthesis of the oligomers, we focused on the anisotropic thermal expansion (ATE) of the flexible PCP/MOFs derived from vibration of the ligands and the metal nodes. Topochemical oligomer synthesis requires the appropriate positioning of several monomers in the crystal structure. The ATE property of PCP/MOF would provide such a situation at a certain temperature, as shown in . Here, we demonstrated the synthesis of various ODAs without an alkyl side chain by use of the PCP/MOFs having two-dimensional (2D) structures.
elements.clean_text: In recent years, remarkable numbers of functional solids such as porous carbon, metal nanoparticles, and organic polymers are reported by use of porous coordination polymers (PCPs) or metal organic frameworks (MOFs) as sacrificial precursors. They are also a useful platform for the molecular synthesis. Sequential dimerization via the [2+2] cycloaddition, [2+2+2] cyclotrimerization, and the formation of an anhydride bridge between free carboxylic groups are examples. These topochemical reactions were conducted by use of the robust crystal structure of PCP/MOFs, and this is not applicable for the various oligomer formations. This is because of the difficulty for the preparation of such topotactic reaction environments for oligomers. Development of the synthetic route of organic oligomers such as ODA without a side alkyl chain by use of PCP/MOFs is therefore of general importance and a challenge. For the synthesis of the oligomers, we focused on the anisotropic thermal expansion (ATE) of the flexible PCP/MOFs derived from vibration of the ligands and the metal nodes. Topochemical oligomer synthesis requires the appropriate positioning of several monomers in the crystal structure. The ATE property of PCP/MOF would provide such a situation at a certain temperature, as shown in . Here, we demonstrated the synthesis of various ODAs without an alkyl side chain by use of the PCP/MOFs having two-dimensional (2D) structures.

elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Illustration of Oligomer Synthesis via the ATE Property of PCP/MOFs

elements.content: We synthesized a bipyridyl ligand having a butadiyne unit for the monomer as shown in . We denote it as bpb (bpb = 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­butadiyne). We first investigated the oligomerization of bpb under a conventional route such as UV irradiation and thermal treatment. However, we recovered bpb, which means the oligomerization does not proceed in either route. We next synthesized a 2D interdigitated framework, [Zn­(ip)­(bpb)] n , which is denoted as ZnCID-24 (CID = coordination polymer with interdigitated structure, ip = isophthalate), as a template for the preparation of ODAs. The crystal structure of ZnCID-24, which was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis at −120 °C, is shown in . Each Zn2+ is in a distorted octahedral geometry, being coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of the bpb at the axial positions and two oxygen atoms from the chelating carboxylate groups of the ip in the equatorial plane. The Zn2+ and ip form a one-dimensional (1D) double-chain structure along the b axis, and the further linkages of those chains via the bpb in the axial positions generate a two-dimensional structure (a,b). The 2D structures are interdigitated mutually to create a stable three-dimensional (3D) assembled architecture from π–π interactions between the aryl planes of the ip (bond distance = 3.7 Å) (c).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

We synthesized a bipyridyl ligand having a butadiyne unit for the monomer as shown in . We denote it as bpb (bpb = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)butadiyne). We first investigated the oligomerization of bpb under a conventional route such as UV irradiation and thermal treatment. However, we recovered bpb, which means the oligomerization does not proceed in either route. We next synthesized a 2D interdigitated framework, [Zn(ip)(bpb)] n , which is denoted as ZnCID-24 (CID = coordination polymer with interdigitated structure, ip = isophthalate), as a template for the preparation of ODAs. The crystal structure of ZnCID-24, which was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis at -120 °C, is shown in . Each Zn2+ is in a distorted octahedral geometry, being coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of the bpb at the axial positions and two oxygen atoms from the chelating carboxylate groups of the ip in the equatorial plane. The Zn2+ and ip form a one-dimensional (1D) double-chain structure along the b axis, and the further linkages of those chains via the bpb in the axial positions generate a two-dimensional structure (a,b). The 2D structures are interdigitated mutually to create a stable three-dimensional (3D) assembled architecture from π-π interactions between the aryl planes of the ip (bond distance = 3.7 Å) (c).

elements.content: Crystal structure of ZnCID-24 showing (a) the 1D double chain of [Zn­(ip)] n , (b) 2D layer structure, and (c) 3D assembled structure, where the gray, blue, red, and green colors denote C, N, O, and Zn, respectively, and H atoms are omitted.
elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structure of ZnCID-24 showing (a) the 1D double chain of [Zn(ip)] n , (b) 2D layer structure, and (c) 3D assembled structure, where the gray, blue, red, and green colors denote C, N, O, and Zn, respectively, and H atoms are omitted.

elements.content: The existence of guest dimethylformamide (DMF) in the crystal structure was confirmed by 1H NMR and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). In the crystal structure, the guest DMF molecules are disordered even at −120 °C; therefore the positions of the guest molecules are not determined. Degas treatment of the single crystal of ZnCID-24 with guest gave the crystal structure of guest-free ZnCID-24. The crystal structure shows only a small difference of the assembled structure when compared to the ZnCID-24 with guest, and therefore the ZnCID-24 is regarded as a robust structure upon guest adsorption/desorption ().
elements.clean_text: The existence of guest dimethylformamide (DMF) in the crystal structure was confirmed by 1H NMR and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). In the crystal structure, the guest DMF molecules are disordered even at -120 °C; therefore the positions of the guest molecules are not determined. Degas treatment of the single crystal of ZnCID-24 with guest gave the crystal structure of guest-free ZnCID-24. The crystal structure shows only a small difference of the assembled structure when compared to the ZnCID-24 with guest, and therefore the ZnCID-24 is regarded as a robust structure upon guest adsorption/desorption ().

elements.content:
In order to investigate the thermal expansion property of the ZnCID-24, we performed variable-temperature single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis over the temperature range between −120 and 26 °C.

As shown in a, the unit cell of the ZnCID-24 shows anisotropic thermal expansion behavior. Thermal vibration of the aryl plane of ip gives the negative expansion along the b axis, and positive expansion along the a axis is caused by slipping of the assembled layer derived from repulsion between the aryl planes of ip. The expansion along the c axis is indicative of the dynamic nature of bpb, and it exhibits the highest expansion behavior. The coefficients of thermal expansion (α) over temperatures between −120 and 26 °C are α a = +44 × 10–6, α b = −20 × 10–6, and α c = +110 × 10–6 K–1, respectively. The coefficient of thermal expansion along the c axis is comparable to that of Nylon-6. We measured the variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) of ZnCID-24 in the temperature range of 28–300 °C (b). The reflection from the c axis shifts toward the lower angle of 2θ, suggesting a gradual structural transformation caused by the heating. The unit cell parameters of the c axis are calculated by the fitting analysis of PXRD patterns. As shown in c, the unit cell parameters along the c axis in the ZnCID-24 exhibit even more expansion behavior over the temperature range of 28–300 °C. The α parameter indicates higher thermal expansion behavior (+479 × 10–6 K–1) compared with the temperature range below 28 °C. Therefore, the ZnCID-24 exhibits specific thermal expansion behavior along the c axis, which indicates the dynamic nature of bpb, according to the heating.
elements.clean_text:
In order to investigate the thermal expansion property of the ZnCID-24, we performed variable-temperature single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis over the temperature range between -120 and 26 °C.

As shown in a, the unit cell of the ZnCID-24 shows anisotropic thermal expansion behavior. Thermal vibration of the aryl plane of ip gives the negative expansion along the b axis, and positive expansion along the a axis is caused by slipping of the assembled layer derived from repulsion between the aryl planes of ip. The expansion along the c axis is indicative of the dynamic nature of bpb, and it exhibits the highest expansion behavior. The coefficients of thermal expansion (α) over temperatures between -120 and 26 °C are α a  = +44 × 10-6, α b  = -20 × 10-6, and α c  = +110 × 10-6 K-1, respectively. The coefficient of thermal expansion along the c axis is comparable to that of Nylon-6. We measured the variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) of ZnCID-24 in the temperature range of 28-300 °C (b). The reflection from the c axis shifts toward the lower angle of 2θ, suggesting a gradual structural transformation caused by the heating. The unit cell parameters of the c axis are calculated by the fitting analysis of PXRD patterns. As shown in c, the unit cell parameters along the c axis in the ZnCID-24 exhibit even more expansion behavior over the temperature range of 28-300 °C. The α parameter indicates higher thermal expansion behavior (+479 × 10-6 K-1) compared with the temperature range below 28 °C. Therefore, the ZnCID-24 exhibits specific thermal expansion behavior along the c axis, which indicates the dynamic nature of bpb, according to the heating.

elements.content: ZnCID-24: (a) temperature-dependent unit cell parameters from −120 °C values determined by single-crystal XRD for the a (blue), b (red), and c axis (black). (b) PXRD patterns from 25 to 300 °C. (c) Temperature-dependent unit cell parameters determined by PXRD for the c axis. (d) TG/DTA profile.
elements.clean_text: 2  ZnCID-24: (a) temperature-dependent unit cell parameters from -120 °C values determined by single-crystal XRD for the a (blue), b (red), and c axis (black). (b) PXRD patterns from 25 to 300 °C. (c) Temperature-dependent unit cell parameters determined by PXRD for the c axis. (d) TG/DTA profile.

elements.content: We performed TGA coupled with the differential thermal analysis (DTA) for the ZnCID-24 as shown in d. TGA shows a weight loss of 4% at 290 °C and then a weight loss of 35% at the temperature of 380–450 °C. From mass spectrometry and 1H NMR analyses, the first weight loss (4% at 230–300 °C) for the ZnCID-24 is the release of bpb, and the second weight loss suggests the decomposition of ip and oligomeric bpb compounds (). On the other hand, DTA exhibits a clear exothermic peak at 300 °C. Each H2ip, bpb, and analogous interdigitated framework with a 4,4′-bipyridyl ligand, [Zn­(ip)­(bpy)] n , does not show an exothermic peak as heating (). The exothermic event at 300 °C for the ZnCID-24 implies cross-linking of bpb in the structure due to the heating. For the cross-linking of the diacetylene moiety, repeated distances of 4.9 Å are required. Upon thermal stimulation of ZnCID-24, the distance between bpb gets close to that distance, and then a cross-linking reaction would proceed in the framework as illustrated in .
elements.clean_text: We performed TGA coupled with the differential thermal analysis (DTA) for the ZnCID-24 as shown in d. TGA shows a weight loss of 4% at 290 °C and then a weight loss of 35% at the temperature of 380-450 °C. From mass spectrometry and 1H NMR analyses, the first weight loss (4% at 230-300 °C) for the ZnCID-24 is the release of bpb, and the second weight loss suggests the decomposition of ip and oligomeric bpb compounds (). On the other hand, DTA exhibits a clear exothermic peak at 300 °C. Each H2ip, bpb, and analogous interdigitated framework with a 4,4'-bipyridyl ligand, [Zn(ip)(bpy)] n , does not show an exothermic peak as heating (). The exothermic event at 300 °C for the ZnCID-24 implies cross-linking of bpb in the structure due to the heating. For the cross-linking of the diacetylene moiety, repeated distances of 4.9 Å are required. Upon thermal stimulation of ZnCID-24, the distance between bpb gets close to that distance, and then a cross-linking reaction would proceed in the framework as illustrated in .

elements.content: To elucidate the oligomer formation in the framework, we conducted heat treatment of the ZnCID-24 at the temperature of 320 °C, where it is above the temperature where it exhibits an exothermic peak from the TG/DTA profile. The heated ZnCID-24 is denoted as H-ZnCID-24, where H indicates heat treatment has completed. Elemental analysis of the H-ZnCID-24 shows that the component derived from the releasing of bpb from the ZnCID-24, PXRD pattern of the H-ZnCID-24 shows no significant diffraction peaks because of the loss of crystallinity (). We performed solid state NMR measurements with 13C dipolar decoupling magic angle spinning (DDMAS) for the ZnCID-24 and the H-ZnCID-24 (a).
elements.clean_text: To elucidate the oligomer formation in the framework, we conducted heat treatment of the ZnCID-24 at the temperature of 320 °C, where it is above the temperature where it exhibits an exothermic peak from the TG/DTA profile. The heated ZnCID-24 is denoted as H-ZnCID-24, where H indicates heat treatment has completed. Elemental analysis of the H-ZnCID-24 shows that the component derived from the releasing of bpb from the ZnCID-24, PXRD pattern of the H-ZnCID-24 shows no significant diffraction peaks because of the loss of crystallinity (). We performed solid state NMR measurements with 13C dipolar decoupling magic angle spinning (DDMAS) for the ZnCID-24 and the H-ZnCID-24 (a).

elements.content: (a) 13C DDMAS spectra of ZnCID-24 (gray) and H-ZnCID-24 (black). (b) CO2 adsorption (solid circles) and desorption (open circles) isotherms of ZnCID-24 (gray) and H-ZnCID-24 (black). (c) MALDI-TOF-MS spectrum of EH-ZnCID-24. (d) Schematic view of cross-linking behavior of bpb in the ZnCID-24.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) 13C DDMAS spectra of ZnCID-24 (gray) and H-ZnCID-24 (black). (b) CO2 adsorption (solid circles) and desorption (open circles) isotherms of ZnCID-24 (gray) and H-ZnCID-24 (black). (c) MALDI-TOF-MS spectrum of EH-ZnCID-24. (d) Schematic view of cross-linking behavior of bpb in the ZnCID-24.

elements.content: A single peak at 78 ppm corresponding to adjacent C–C triple bonds in bpb is observed in the ZnCID-24, whereas the H-ZnCID-24 does not have the peak, because all the adjacent C–C triple bonds of bpb reacted as heating. The peaks from the generated C–C triple and double bonds in the H-ZnCID-24 are at the aromatic region of 110–160 ppm due to the change of bond environment. To observe the porous structure of the framework after the thermal treatment, we performed CO2 adsorption measurement of the H-ZnCID-24 at −78 °C. The adsorption isotherm in b shows a gradual rise from the low relative pressure region, which suggests the presence of a microporous structure. The adsorbed amount of CO2 in the H-ZnCID-24 is 42 mL g–1. On the other hand, although the ZnCID-24 also shows similar adsorption behavior, the adsorbed amount of CO2 is 20 mL g–1. The difference in adsorbed amount between the H-ZnCID-24 and the ZnCID-24 would result from the increase of the adsorbed site of CO2 molecules due to the structure transformation of bpb.
elements.clean_text: A single peak at 78 ppm corresponding to adjacent C-C triple bonds in bpb is observed in the ZnCID-24, whereas the H-ZnCID-24 does not have the peak, because all the adjacent C-C triple bonds of bpb reacted as heating. The peaks from the generated C-C triple and double bonds in the H-ZnCID-24 are at the aromatic region of 110-160 ppm due to the change of bond environment. To observe the porous structure of the framework after the thermal treatment, we performed CO2 adsorption measurement of the H-ZnCID-24 at -78 °C. The adsorption isotherm in b shows a gradual rise from the low relative pressure region, which suggests the presence of a microporous structure. The adsorbed amount of CO2 in the H-ZnCID-24 is 42 mL g-1. On the other hand, although the ZnCID-24 also shows similar adsorption behavior, the adsorbed amount of CO2 is 20 mL g-1. The difference in adsorbed amount between the H-ZnCID-24 and the ZnCID-24 would result from the increase of the adsorbed site of CO2 molecules due to the structure transformation of bpb.

elements.content: We etched the H-ZnCID-24 with an EDTA·4Na solution (EDTA = ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid) to remove Zn and ip. The etched sample is denoted as EH-ZnCID-24. The matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization time-of-flight mass spectrum (MALDI-TOF-MS) of the EH-ZnCID-24 is shown in c. The EH-ZnCID-24 shows the repeated peaks of m/z = 204.1, which corresponds to the molecular weight of bpb. On the other hand, the EH-ZnCID-24 does not show the peak of m/z = 204.1 derived from the bpb monomer and dimer in the mass spectra below m/z = 300 measured by APCI-MS (). As a further characterization, we conducted elemental analysis for the EH-ZnCID-24, and the result matched the protonated bpb oligomer (). Thus, it proves that the cross-linking reaction of bpb in the ZnCID-24 occurs upon heating to create the ODA without a side alkyl chain, as shown in d. Both ionization profiles of the MALDI and the APCI suggest the trimer is the dominant product for this case. On the other hand, a 20-unit oligomer as the maximum cross-linking product is also observed. The oligomer with long units would be formed from small crystal particles, which are able to transfer the heat quickly.
elements.clean_text: We etched the H-ZnCID-24 with an EDTA⋅4Na solution (EDTA = ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid) to remove Zn and ip. The etched sample is denoted as EH-ZnCID-24. The matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization time-of-flight mass spectrum (MALDI-TOF-MS) of the EH-ZnCID-24 is shown in c. The EH-ZnCID-24 shows the repeated peaks of m/z = 204.1, which corresponds to the molecular weight of bpb. On the other hand, the EH-ZnCID-24 does not show the peak of m/z = 204.1 derived from the bpb monomer and dimer in the mass spectra below m/z = 300 measured by APCI-MS (). As a further characterization, we conducted elemental analysis for the EH-ZnCID-24, and the result matched the protonated bpb oligomer (). Thus, it proves that the cross-linking reaction of bpb in the ZnCID-24 occurs upon heating to create the ODA without a side alkyl chain, as shown in d. Both ionization profiles of the MALDI and the APCI suggest the trimer is the dominant product for this case. On the other hand, a 20-unit oligomer as the maximum cross-linking product is also observed. The oligomer with long units would be formed from small crystal particles, which are able to transfer the heat quickly.

elements.content: We studied the mechanism of the preference for trimer formation. To investigate the effect of reaction temperature for the oligomerization behavior, we heated the ZnCID-24 at the temperature of 200, 250, and 300 °C and characterized the oligomerization by APCI-MS measurements (). The oligomer formation (trimer dominant) is only observed for the reaction at 300 °C, and the products prepared at 200 and 250 °C do not contain any oligomer species. We next changed the heating rate from 5 °C min–1 to 1 and 15 °C min–1 to study the influence of the heating rate on the formation of oligomer. The products are the same as those obtained from 5 °C min–1, and the oligomerization is independent of the heating rate (). From the results of 1H NMR, TGA-MS, and the reactions under different temperatures or heating rates, the cross-linking happens due to ATE along the release of partial bpb in the structure and is under a thermodynamic process.
elements.clean_text: We studied the mechanism of the preference for trimer formation. To investigate the effect of reaction temperature for the oligomerization behavior, we heated the ZnCID-24 at the temperature of 200, 250, and 300 °C and characterized the oligomerization by APCI-MS measurements (). The oligomer formation (trimer dominant) is only observed for the reaction at 300 °C, and the products prepared at 200 and 250 °C do not contain any oligomer species. We next changed the heating rate from 5 °C min-1 to 1 and 15 °C min-1 to study the influence of the heating rate on the formation of oligomer. The products are the same as those obtained from 5 °C min-1, and the oligomerization is independent of the heating rate (). From the results of 1H NMR, TGA-MS, and the reactions under different temperatures or heating rates, the cross-linking happens due to ATE along the release of partial bpb in the structure and is under a thermodynamic process.

elements.content: In order to determine the growth direction of the oligomer, we prepared another interdigitated framework with naphthalene dicarboxylate instead of ip, [Zn­(ndc)­(bpb)] n , which is denoted as ZnCID-25 (, ndc = naphthalene 2,7-dicarboxylate).
elements.clean_text: In order to determine the growth direction of the oligomer, we prepared another interdigitated framework with naphthalene dicarboxylate instead of ip, [Zn(ndc)(bpb)] n , which is denoted as ZnCID-25 (, ndc = naphthalene 2,7-dicarboxylate).

elements.content: (a) 1D double chain of [Zn­(ip)] n from ZnCID-24 and [Zn­(ndc)] n from ZnCID-25. (b) MALDI-TOF-MS spectrum of EH-ZnCID-25.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) 1D double chain of [Zn(ip)] n  from ZnCID-24 and [Zn(ndc)] n  from ZnCID-25. (b) MALDI-TOF-MS spectrum of EH-ZnCID-25.

elements.content: ZnCID-25 is constructed from 1D ribbon chains with an eight-membered ring of Zn2+, two ndc moieties, and bpb coordinating to Zn2+, which forms the 2D layers, and the layers are also interdigitated to create a 3D assembled structure. As shown in a, the distance between bpb along the b axis is 2.4 Å larger than that of the ZnCID-24. We heated the ZnCID-25 at 320 °C for 15 min and then etched the heated sample by using an EDTA·4Na solution in the same manner as the case of the ZnCID-24. As shown in b, a MALDI-TOF-MS of the EH-ZnCID-25 shows the repeated peaks, and the trimer formation is dominant. The results suggest that the elongation of the b axis by applying ndc instead of ip in the structure does not affect the formation of ODAs, and they grow along the a axis, which is the interlayer direction.
elements.clean_text: ZnCID-25 is constructed from 1D ribbon chains with an eight-membered ring of Zn2+, two ndc moieties, and bpb coordinating to Zn2+, which forms the 2D layers, and the layers are also interdigitated to create a 3D assembled structure. As shown in a, the distance between bpb along the b axis is 2.4 Å larger than that of the ZnCID-24. We heated the ZnCID-25 at 320 °C for 15 min and then etched the heated sample by using an EDTA⋅4Na solution in the same manner as the case of the ZnCID-24. As shown in b, a MALDI-TOF-MS of the EH-ZnCID-25 shows the repeated peaks, and the trimer formation is dominant. The results suggest that the elongation of the b axis by applying ndc instead of ip in the structure does not affect the formation of ODAs, and they grow along the a axis, which is the interlayer direction.

elements.content: We further investigated the effect of the metal ion in the interdigitated PCP structure for the formation of ODA. We synthesized different metal derivatives of the ZnCID-24: CoCID-24 and CuCID-24. Both of the crystal structures show analogous interdigitated motifs, whereas they exhibit differences in bond distances and angles (). Both of the TG/DTA profiles exhibit exothermic peaks attributed to the oligomerization at the temperature of 330 and 260 °C, respectively (). Accordingly, we characterized the oligomerization of the etched samples by MALDI-TOF-MS measurements (a).
elements.clean_text: We further investigated the effect of the metal ion in the interdigitated PCP structure for the formation of ODA. We synthesized different metal derivatives of the ZnCID-24: CoCID-24 and CuCID-24. Both of the crystal structures show analogous interdigitated motifs, whereas they exhibit differences in bond distances and angles (). Both of the TG/DTA profiles exhibit exothermic peaks attributed to the oligomerization at the temperature of 330 and 260 °C, respectively (). Accordingly, we characterized the oligomerization of the etched samples by MALDI-TOF-MS measurements (a).

elements.content: (a) MALDI-TOF-MS spectra of the (right) EH-CuCID-24 and (left) EH-CoCID-24. (b) Emission spectra of EH-ZnCID-24 (black), EH-CoCID-24 (blue), EH-CuCID-24 (red), and EH-ZnCID-25 (green) in water.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) MALDI-TOF-MS spectra of the (right) EH-CuCID-24 and (left) EH-CoCID-24. (b) Emission spectra of EH-ZnCID-24 (black), EH-CoCID-24 (blue), EH-CuCID-24 (red), and EH-ZnCID-25 (green) in water.

elements.content: The etched product from H-CoCID-24 (EH-CoCID-24) provides mainly trimer molecules, which is similar to that of the EH-ZnCID-24, whereas the EH-CuCID-24 provides dimers predominantly. The ATE property of PCP/MOFs is influenced by the metal ions (), and the observed distinct formation of ODAs would be derived from the different ATE property of each interdigitated structure. The extent of the cross-linking process in ODAs was monitored by recording the emission profile of the etched products. As shown in b, the EH-CuCID-24, in which dimer formation is dominant, exhibits an emission band at 420 nm. On the other hand, the emission band of the EH-ZnCID-24, the EH-CoCID-24, and the EH-ZnCID-25, in which trimer formation is dominant, red-shifted around 570 nm, suggesting increased conjugation. These fluorescence properties also support the emission behavior from the oligomer state.
elements.clean_text: The etched product from H-CoCID-24 (EH-CoCID-24) provides mainly trimer molecules, which is similar to that of the EH-ZnCID-24, whereas the EH-CuCID-24 provides dimers predominantly. The ATE property of PCP/MOFs is influenced by the metal ions (), and the observed distinct formation of ODAs would be derived from the different ATE property of each interdigitated structure. The extent of the cross-linking process in ODAs was monitored by recording the emission profile of the etched products. As shown in b, the EH-CuCID-24, in which dimer formation is dominant, exhibits an emission band at 420 nm. On the other hand, the emission band of the EH-ZnCID-24, the EH-CoCID-24, and the EH-ZnCID-25, in which trimer formation is dominant, red-shifted around 570 nm, suggesting increased conjugation. These fluorescence properties also support the emission behavior from the oligomer state.

elements.content: In this work, we employed the ATE property of the flexible PCP/MOFs for the topochemical synthesis of ODAs without alkyl side chains. ZnCID-24, having a 2D structure, expands the crystallographic unit cell along the c axis due to the heating. It is accompanied by the releasing of bpb, and then bpb forms an oligomer in the framework at temperatures above 300 °C. The oligomeric unit of the products depends on the metal ions in the frameworks, where Zn2+ and Co2+ show trimer formation and Cu2+ shows dimer formation predominantly. The ATE property is often observed in PCP/MOFs, but no attempt is reported for the synthesis of functional molecules so far. The proposed approach in this work would inspire a new route of synthesizing various functional oligomers.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this work, we employed the ATE property of the flexible PCP/MOFs for the topochemical synthesis of ODAs without alkyl side chains. ZnCID-24, having a 2D structure, expands the crystallographic unit cell along the c axis due to the heating. It is accompanied by the releasing of bpb, and then bpb forms an oligomer in the framework at temperatures above 300 °C. The oligomeric unit of the products depends on the metal ions in the frameworks, where Zn2+ and Co2+ show trimer formation and Cu2+ shows dimer formation predominantly. The ATE property is often observed in PCP/MOFs, but no attempt is reported for the synthesis of functional molecules so far. The proposed approach in this work would inspire a new route of synthesizing various functional oligomers.

elements.content: Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (298 mg, 1.0 mmol), isophthalic acid (166 mg, 1.0 mmol), bpb (204 mg, 1.0 mmol), DMF (40 mL), and MeOH (10 mL) were added to a 150 mL screw-top glass vial, then heated at 80 °C for 24 h. Pale yellow crystals thus produced were washed with DMF (50 mL × 2) and MeOH (20 mL × 1). In order to remove the guest solvent, the crystals were immersed in deoxidized MeOH (50 mL) overnight and then degassed under vacuum at 80 °C for 12 h. Synthetic procedures of ZnCID-25, CuCID24, and CoCID-24 are mentioned in the .
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of ZnCID-24

Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (298 mg, 1.0 mmol), isophthalic acid (166 mg, 1.0 mmol), bpb (204 mg, 1.0 mmol), DMF (40 mL), and MeOH (10 mL) were added to a 150 mL screw-top glass vial, then heated at 80 °C for 24 h. Pale yellow crystals thus produced were washed with DMF (50 mL × 2) and MeOH (20 mL × 1). In order to remove the guest solvent, the crystals were immersed in deoxidized MeOH (50 mL) overnight and then degassed under vacuum at 80 °C for 12 h. Synthetic procedures of ZnCID-25, CuCID24, and CoCID-24 are mentioned in the .

elements.content: The degassed sample (100 mg) was homogeneously placed on a ceramic boat (16 × 12 × 80 mm) and then heated to the target temperature with a heating rate of 5 °C min–1 under a flow of nitrogen (0.5 L min–1). After holding for 15 min at the target temperature, a H-CID derivative was obtained. Target temperatures for ZnCID-24, ZnCID-25, CuCID-24, and CoCID-24 of 320, 320, 290, and 380 °C, respectively, were adoped.
elements.clean_text:
Heat Treatment of CID Derivatives

The degassed sample (100 mg) was homogeneously placed on a ceramic boat (16 × 12 × 80 mm) and then heated to the target temperature with a heating rate of 5 °C min-1 under a flow of nitrogen (0.5 L min-1). After holding for 15 min at the target temperature, a H-CID derivative was obtained. Target temperatures for ZnCID-24, ZnCID-25, CuCID-24, and CoCID-24 of 320, 320, 290, and 380 °C, respectively, were adoped.

elements.content: EH-CID derivatives were prepared by etching of a H-CID derivative with a 0.05 M EDTA solution. Typically, H-ZnCID-24 (30 mg) was stirred in 0.05 M EDTA solution (5 mL) overnight, and then an insoluble residue, which is the EH-CID derivative, was washed repeatedly with distilled water (5 mL × 2) and MeOH (5 mL × 1). For the MALDI-TOF-MS and the fluorescence measurements, the EH-CID derivative was further dissolved in 3 M HCl solution, and then the solution was evaporated.
elements.clean_text:
Etching of H-CID Derivatives

EH-CID derivatives were prepared by etching of a H-CID derivative with a 0.05 M EDTA solution. Typically, H-ZnCID-24 (30 mg) was stirred in 0.05 M EDTA solution (5 mL) overnight, and then an insoluble residue, which is the EH-CID derivative, was washed repeatedly with distilled water (5 mL × 2) and MeOH (5 mL × 1). For the MALDI-TOF-MS and the fluorescence measurements, the EH-CID derivative was further dissolved in 3 M HCl solution, and then the solution was evaporated.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were performed with a Rigaku AFC10 diffractometer with a Rigaku Saturn Kappa CCD system equipped with a MicroMax-007 HF/VariMax rotating-anode X-ray generator with confocal monochromated Mo Kα radiation. The structures were solved by a direct method (SHELXT-2014) and refined by full-matrix least-squares procedures on F 2 for all reflections (SHELXL-2017). The hydrogen atoms were positioned geometrically and refined using a riding model. In the crystal structures of ZnCID-24, CuCID-24, and CoCID-24, guest DMF is highly disordered, and the SQUEEZE function of PLATON was used to eliminate the contribution of the electron density in the solvent region from the intensity data. The solvent-free model was employed for the final refinement. For the refinement of the crystal structure of ZnCID-24, we removed 97 electrons by using the SQUEEZE command. This corresponds to one DMF, which was confirmed by 1H NMR and TGA. We estimated the percentage of solvent-accessible voids by using PLATON software, and these are 32% for guest-free ZnCID24.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction Analyses

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were performed with a Rigaku AFC10 diffractometer with a Rigaku Saturn Kappa CCD system equipped with a MicroMax-007 HF/VariMax rotating-anode X-ray generator with confocal monochromated Mo Kα radiation. The structures were solved by a direct method (SHELXT-2014) and refined by full-matrix least-squares procedures on F 2 for all reflections (SHELXL-2017). The hydrogen atoms were positioned geometrically and refined using a riding model. In the crystal structures of ZnCID-24, CuCID-24, and CoCID-24, guest DMF is highly disordered, and the SQUEEZE function of PLATON was used to eliminate the contribution of the electron density in the solvent region from the intensity data. The solvent-free model was employed for the final refinement. For the refinement of the crystal structure of ZnCID-24, we removed 97 electrons by using the SQUEEZE command. This corresponds to one DMF, which was confirmed by 1H NMR and TGA. We estimated the percentage of solvent-accessible voids by using PLATON software, and these are 32% for guest-free ZnCID24.

elements.content: Variable-temperature PXRD data were collected on a Rigaku SmartLab multipurpose diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation) equipped with a temperature changer attachment. The unit cell parameters of a, b, and c axes were calculated by the fitting analysis of PXRD patterns using PDXL software from Rigaku. TG/DTA was performed using a Rigaku Thermo Plus TG 8120 in the temperature range from 30 to 500 °C under a flowing N2 gas atmosphere with the ramping rate of 5 °C min–1. TG-MS was performed with a Rigaku Thermo Plus EVO II equipped with ThermoMass Photo/S by using the electron impact ionization method. FT-IR was performed with a Thermo Fisher Scientific Nicolet iS5. Liquid state 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a JEOL JNM-ECS400. Solid state 13C DDMAS NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Biospin, ADVANCE III 400 NMR spectrometer. The spinning rate for DDMAS spectra was 12 kHz. MALDI-TOF-MS was performed with a Bruker Daltonics Ultraflex. As a matrix molecule, we used 2,5-dihydroxybenzoic acid. APCI-MS was performed with a Thermo Fisher Scientific EXACTIVE. CO2 adsorption isotherms were measured at −78 °C by a BELSORP-mini with dry ice and MeOH dewar. PCP samples were activated by heating at 120 °C under reduced pressure (<10–2 Pa) for 12 h prior to the measurement. The excitation and emission spectra for the etched compounds were measured using a Horiba FluoroLog-3 instrument.
elements.clean_text:
General Methods

Variable-temperature PXRD data were collected on a Rigaku SmartLab multipurpose diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation) equipped with a temperature changer attachment. The unit cell parameters of a, b, and c axes were calculated by the fitting analysis of PXRD patterns using PDXL software from Rigaku. TG/DTA was performed using a Rigaku Thermo Plus TG 8120 in the temperature range from 30 to 500 °C under a flowing N2 gas atmosphere with the ramping rate of 5 °C min-1. TG-MS was performed with a Rigaku Thermo Plus EVO II equipped with ThermoMass Photo/S by using the electron impact ionization method. FT-IR was performed with a Thermo Fisher Scientific Nicolet iS5. Liquid state 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a JEOL JNM-ECS400. Solid state 13C DDMAS NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Biospin, ADVANCE III 400 NMR spectrometer. The spinning rate for DDMAS spectra was 12 kHz. MALDI-TOF-MS was performed with a Bruker Daltonics Ultraflex. As a matrix molecule, we used 2,5-dihydroxybenzoic acid. APCI-MS was performed with a Thermo Fisher Scientific EXACTIVE. CO2 adsorption isotherms were measured at -78 °C by a BELSORP-mini with dry ice and MeOH dewar. PCP samples were activated by heating at 120 °C under reduced pressure (<10-2 Pa) for 12 h prior to the measurement. The excitation and emission spectra for the etched compounds were measured using a Horiba FluoroLog-3 instrument.

cln_elements.content:
Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (298 mg, 1.0 mmol), isophthalic acid (166 mg, 1.0 mmol), bpb (204 mg, 1.0 mmol), DMF (40 mL), and MeOH (10 mL) were added to a 150 mL screw-top glass vial, then heated at 80 °C for 24 h. Pale yellow crystals thus produced were washed with DMF (50 mL × 2) and MeOH (20 mL × 1). In order to remove the guest solvent, the crystals were immersed in deoxidized MeOH (50 mL) overnight and then degassed under vacuum at 80 °C for 12 h. Synthetic procedures of ZnCID-25, CuCID24, and CoCID-24 are mentioned in the .

Heat Treatment of CID Derivatives

Target temperatures for ZnCID-24, ZnCID-25, CuCID-24, and CoCID-24 of 320, 320, 290, and 380 °C, respectively, were adoped.

Experimental Section

Synthesis of ZnCID-24

Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (298 mg, 1.0 mmol), isophthalic acid (166 mg, 1.0 mmol), bpb (204 mg, 1.0 mmol), DMF (40 mL), and MeOH (10 mL) were added to a 150 mL screw-top glass vial, then heated at 80 °C for 24 h. Pale yellow crystals thus produced were washed with DMF (50 mL × 2) and MeOH (20 mL × 1). In order to remove the guest solvent, the crystals were immersed in deoxidized MeOH (50 mL) overnight and then degassed under vacuum at 80 °C for 12 h. cln_elements.content:
In order to investigate the thermal expansion property of the ZnCID-24, we performed variable-temperature single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis over the temperature range between −120 and 26 °C.

As shown in a, the unit cell of the ZnCID-24 shows anisotropic thermal expansion behavior. Thermal vibration of the aryl plane of ip gives the negative expansion along the b axis, and positive expansion along the a axis is caused by slipping of the assembled layer derived from repulsion between the aryl planes of ip. The expansion along the c axis is indicative of the dynamic nature of bpb, and it exhibits the highest expansion behavior. The coefficients of thermal expansion (α) over temperatures between −120 and 26 °C are α a = +44 × 10–6, α b = −20 × 10–6, and α c = +110 × 10–6 K–1, respectively. The coefficient of thermal expansion along the c axis is comparable to that of Nylon-6. We measured the variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) of ZnCID-24 in the temperature range of 28–300 °C (b). The reflection from the c axis shifts toward the lower angle of 2θ, suggesting a gradual structural transformation caused by the heating. The unit cell parameters of the c axis are calculated by the fitting analysis of PXRD patterns. As shown in c, the unit cell parameters along the c axis in the ZnCID-24 exhibit even more expansion behavior over the temperature range of 28–300 °C. The α parameter indicates higher thermal expansion behavior (+479 × 10–6 K–1) compared with the temperature range below 28 °C. Therefore, the ZnCID-24 exhibits specific thermal expansion behavior along the c axis, which indicates the dynamic nature of bpb, according to the heating.

We performed TGA coupled with the differential thermal analysis (DTA) for the ZnCID-24 as shown in d. TGA shows a weight loss of 4% at 290 °C and then a weight loss of 35% at the temperature of 380–450 °C. From mass spectrometry and 1H NMR analyses, the first weight loss (4% at 230–300 °C) for the ZnCID-24 is the release of bpb, and the second weight loss suggests the decomposition of ip and oligomeric bpb compounds (). On the other hand, DTA exhibits a clear exothermic peak at 300 °C. Each H2ip, bpb, and analogous interdigitated framework with a 4,4′-bipyridyl ligand, [Zn­(ip)­(bpy)] n , does not show an exothermic peak as heating (). The exothermic event at 300 °C for the ZnCID-24 implies cross-linking of bpb in the structure due to the heating. For the cross-linking of the diacetylene moiety, repeated distances of 4.9 Å are required. Upon thermal stimulation of ZnCID-24, the distance between bpb gets close to that distance, and then a cross-linking reaction would proceed in the framework as illustrated in .
cln_elements.clean_text:
In order to investigate the thermal expansion property of the ZnCID-24, we performed variable-temperature single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis over the temperature range between -120 and 26 °C.

As shown in a, the unit cell of the ZnCID-24 shows anisotropic thermal expansion behavior. Thermal vibration of the aryl plane of ip gives the negative expansion along the b axis, and positive expansion along the a axis is caused by slipping of the assembled layer derived from repulsion between the aryl planes of ip. The expansion along the c axis is indicative of the dynamic nature of bpb, and it exhibits the highest expansion behavior. The coefficients of thermal expansion (α) over temperatures between -120 and 26 °C are α a  = +44 × 10-6, α b  = -20 × 10-6, and α c  = +110 × 10-6 K-1, respectively. The coefficient of thermal expansion along the c axis is comparable to that of Nylon-6. We measured the variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) of ZnCID-24 in the temperature range of 28-300 °C (b). The reflection from the c axis shifts toward the lower angle of 2θ, suggesting a gradual structural transformation caused by the heating. The unit cell parameters of the c axis are calculated by the fitting analysis of PXRD patterns. As shown in c, the unit cell parameters along the c axis in the ZnCID-24 exhibit even more expansion behavior over the temperature range of 28-300 °C. The α parameter indicates higher thermal expansion behavior (+479 × 10-6 K-1) compared with the temperature range below 28 °C. Therefore, the ZnCID-24 exhibits specific thermal expansion behavior along the c axis, which indicates the dynamic nature of bpb, according to the heating.

We performed TGA coupled with the differential thermal analysis (DTA) for the ZnCID-24 as shown in d. TGA shows a weight loss of 4% at 290 °C and then a weight loss of 35% at the temperature of 380-450 °C. From mass spectrometry and 1H NMR analyses, the first weight loss (4% at 230-300 °C) for the ZnCID-24 is the release of bpb, and the second weight loss suggests the decomposition of ip and oligomeric bpb compounds (). On the other hand, DTA exhibits a clear exothermic peak at 300 °C. Each H2ip, bpb, and analogous interdigitated framework with a 4,4'-bipyridyl ligand, [Zn(ip)(bpy)] n , does not show an exothermic peak as heating (). The exothermic event at 300 °C for the ZnCID-24 implies cross-linking of bpb in the structure due to the heating. For the cross-linking of the diacetylene moiety, repeated distances of 4.9 Å are required. Upon thermal stimulation of ZnCID-24, the distance between bpb gets close to that distance, and then a cross-linking reaction would proceed in the framework as illustrated in .

metadata.title:
Synthesis
of Oligodiacetylene Derivatives from Flexible
Porous Coordination Frameworks
